block.p: A shad bake sponsored by the River Project and the Hudson River Foundation will be given on Sunday from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. at the River Project, Pier 26 at West Street near Canal Street. Information about shad and Hudson River wildlife will be available and, starting at 2 p.m., free samples of shad dishes will be served.

On Monday at the Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street, the Culinary Historians of New York is sponsoring a talk by Elizabeth Andoh, a food writer who specializes in Japan, about ekiben, food sold in Japanese train stations. The fee is $25 for members, $22 for students and members over 65, $30 for nonmembers: (212) 334-4175.

A shad bake sponsored by the River Project and the Hudson River Foundation will be given on Sunday from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. at the River Project, Pier 26 at West Street near Canal Street. Information about shad and Hudson River wildlife will be available and, starting at 2 p.m., free samples of shad dishes will be served.

On Monday at the Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street, the Culinary Historians of New York is sponsoring a talk by Elizabeth Andoh, a food writer who specializes in Japan, about ekiben, food sold in Japanese train stations. The fee is $25 for members, $22 for students and members over 65, $30 for nonmembers: (212) 334-4175.

A cabaret show on cheese, ''Say Cheese,'' will be given on April 28 at 7:30 p.m. at the Laurie Beechman Theater at the West Bank Cafe, 407 West 42nd Street. Jackie Gordon of Divalicious Inc., a company that pairs food and music, will perform. There will be tastings of cheeses from the Artisanal Cheese Center, with wines.
Additional performances will be given on April 29 and throughout May and June. Tickets are $60: www.ticketcentral.com.

Ukrainian poetry will be recited during a dinner on May 3 at 6:30 p.m., at Kiev East restaurant, 117 Second Avenue (Seventh Street). The event is sponsored by two nonprofit groups, Word Feast and City Lore, which studies urban culture. Tickets are $40 for members of City Lore and the Queens Council on the Arts, $45 for nonmembers.

The series continues on May 8 at 8 p.m., with a dinner at Shaheen Sweets, 72-09 Broadway, Jackson Heights, Queens, with South Asian music and poetry, $40 and $45; on May 15 at 7 p.m. at a loft at 1255 Fifth Avenue (107th Street), with a dinner with Iranian poetry, $45 and $50; and on May 16 at 6 p.m., with a dinner at Tripoli Restaurant, 156 Atlantic Avenue (Clinton Street), Brooklyn, with Yemeni music and poetry, also $45 and $50. For tickets: (212) 529-1955.
